table.php

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 <table class="manual" id="basic">
00002   <caption>tables</caption>
00003   <tr>
00004     <th>Statement</th>
00005     <th>Description</th>
00006   </tr>
00007   <tr>
00008     <td colspan="2">
00009       <p>Tables are named structures which can hold a collection of addresses and
00010          networks. Lookups against tables in pf(4) are relatively fast, making a
00011          single rule with tables much more efficient, in terms of processor usage
00012          and memory consumption, than a large number of rules which differ only in
00013          IP address (either created explicitly or automatically by rule expansion).</p>
00014 
00015       <p>Tables can be used as the source or destination of filter rules, scrub
00016          rules or translation rules such as nat or rdr (see below for details on
00017          the various rule types).  Tables can also be used for the redirect address 
00018          of nat and rdr rules and in the routing options of filter rules,
00019          but only for round-robin pools.</p>
00020 
00021       <p>Tables can be defined with any of the following pfctl(8) mechanisms.  As
00022          with macros, reserved words may not be used as table names.</p>
00023     </td>
00024   </tr>
00025   <tr>
00026     <td>manually</td>
00027     <td>Persistent tables can be manually created with the add or
00028         replace option of pfctl(8), before or after the ruleset has
00029         been loaded.</td>
00030   </tr>
00031   <tr>
00032     <td>pf.conf</td>
00033     <td>Table definitions can be placed directly in this file, and
00034         loaded at the same time as other rules are loaded, atomically.
00035         Table definitions inside pf.conf use the table statement, and
00036         are especially useful to define non-persistent tables.  The
00037         contents of a pre-existing table defined without a list of addresses 
00038         to initialize it is not altered when pf.conf is loaded.
00039         A table initialized with the empty list, { }, will be cleared
00040         on load.</td>
00041   </tr>
00042   <tr>
00043     <td colspan="2">
00044       <p>Tables may be defined with the following two attributes:</p>
00045       
00046       <table>
00047         <tr>
00048           <td class="key">persist</td>
00049           <td>The persist flag forces the kernel to keep the table even when
00050               no rules refer to it.  If the flag is not set, the kernel will
00051               automatically remove the table when the last rule referring to
00052               it is flushed.
00053           </td>
00054         </tr>
00055         <tr>
00056           <td class="key">const</td>
00057           <td>The const flag prevents the user from altering the contents of
00058               the table once it has been created.  Without that flag, pfctl(8)
00059               can be used to add or remove addresses from the table at any
00060               time, even when running with securelevel(7) = 2.</td>
00061         </tr>
00062       </table>
00063 
00064       <p>For example,</p>
00065 
00066 <pre>
00067 table &lt;private&gt; const { 10/8, 172.16/12, 192.168/16 }
00068 table &lt;badhosts&gt; persist
00069 block on fxp0 from { &lt;private&gt;, &lt;badhosts&gt; } to any
00070 </pre>
00071 
00072       <p>creates a table called private, to hold RFC 1918 private network blocks,
00073          and a table called badhosts, which is initially empty.  A filter rule is
00074          set up to block all traffic coming from addresses listed in either table.
00075          The private table cannot have its contents changed and the badhosts table
00076          will exist even when no active filter rules reference it.  Addresses may
00077          later be added to the badhosts table, so that traffic from these hosts
00078          can be blocked by using</p>
00079 
00080         <code># pfctl -t badhosts -Tadd 204.92.77.111</code>
00081 
00082       <p>A table can also be initialized with an address list specified in one or
00083          more external files, using the following syntax:</p>
00084 
00085 <pre>
00086 table &lt;spam&gt; persist file "/etc/spammers" file "/etc/openrelays"
00087 block on fxp0 from &lt;spam&gt; to any
00088 </pre>
00089 
00090       <p>The files /etc/spammers and /etc/openrelays list IP addresses, one per
00091          line.  Any lines beginning with a # are treated as comments and ignored.
00092          In addition to being specified by IP address, hosts may also be specified
00093          by their hostname.  When the resolver is called to add a hostname to a
00094          table, all resulting IPv4 and IPv6 addresses are placed into the table.
00095          IP addresses can also be entered in a table by specifying a valid interface 
00096          name or the self keyword, in which case all addresses assigned to
00097          the interface(s) will be added to the table.
00098       </p>
00099     </td>
00100   </tr>
00101 </table>
00102
